title: George Fletcher (communist)
text:
George Henry Fletcher (7 September 1879 – 8 June 1958) was a <a href="British%20people">British</a> <a href="communist">communist</a> activist and <a href="baker">baker</a>.
Life.
Born in <a href="Horncastle%2C%20Lincolnshire">Horncastle</a> in <a href="Lincolnshire">Lincolnshire</a>, Fletcher completed an apprenticeship as a baker and, after a short period working as a miner, found work at Simmersons bakery in <a href="Sheffield">Sheffield</a>. There, he started a branch of the <a href="Amalgamated%20Union%20of%20Operative%20Bakers">Amalgamated Union of Operative Bakers</a>, and became its chair.
In 1898, Fletcher joined the <a href="Sheffield%20Socialist%20Society">Sheffield Socialist Society</a> (SSS), and around this time, he also started a small bakery of his own. In 1902, he worked with other SSS members to form a branch of the <a href="Social%20Democratic%20Federation">Social Democratic Federation</a> (SDF). He was an agreed joint <a href="Labour%20Representation%20Committee%20%281900%29">Labour</a> candidate in the 1905 local elections in <a href="Burngreave">Burngreave</a>, losing by only four votes. He also began speaking regularly at open air meetings for the party. In 1910, he was fined 40 shillings for speaking in <a href="High%20Hazels%20Park">High Hazels Park</a>; soon after, he was sentenced to 56 days in prison for speaking in <a href="Hillsborough%20Park">Hillsborough Park</a>.
Fletcher was elected to the executive committee of the <a href="Sheffield%20Trades%20and%20Labour%20Council">Sheffield Trades and Labour Council</a> in 1914, and as vice-chair in 1915. He organised <a href="opposition%20to%20World%20War%20I">anti-war</a> rallies, and was prominent in the <a href="No%20Conscription%20Fellowship">No Conscription Fellowship</a>. He also played a role in supporting the <a href="Sheffield%20Workers%27%20Committee">Sheffield Workers' Committee</a>, and was prominent in the bakers' national strike of 1919.
In 1920, Fletcher was a founder of both the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20Great%20Britain">Communist Party of Great Britain</a> (CPGB) and the Sheffield <a href="National%20Unemployed%20Workers%20Movement">National Unemployed Workers Movement</a>. In 1921, he was sentenced to three months in prison on charges of <a href="sedition">sedition</a> for speaking in favour of a miners' strike. Fletcher was later appointed as the treasurer of the <a href="National%20Minority%20Movement">National Minority Movement</a>.
Although he was chair of the local CPGB branch, Fletcher was also adopted as a <a href="Labour%20Party%20%28UK%29">Labour Party</a> candidate, and was elected to the <a href="Board%20of%20Guardians">Board of Guardians</a> in 1922, representing <a href="Darnall">Darnall</a>, and acting as the board's treasurer. He was expelled from Labour in 1928, and then stood for the CPGB in <a href="Sheffield%20Attercliffe%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Sheffield Attercliffe</a> at the <a href="1929%20United%20Kingdom%20general%20election">1929</a> and <a href="1931%20United%20Kingdom%20general%20election">1931 general election</a>s. The Board of Guardians was abolished in 1929, and Fletcher stood for <a href="Sheffield%20City%20Council">Sheffield City Council</a> unsuccessfully that year, then in 1932 and 1935 in <a href="Manor%2C%20Sheffield">Manor</a>, each time taking more than 1,000 votes.
Fletcher's son, also George Fletcher, was a founder member of the <a href="Young%20Communist%20League%20%28Britain%29">Young Communist League</a> in 1921. In 1923, the two set up a new venture, running bread vans to supply their own shops, which grew into a large and profitable business, which remained in the family until it was sold to <a href="Northern%20Foods">Northern Foods</a> in 1999 for £40 million.
Fletcher retired near the start of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, continuing to support the CPGB financially. In his spare time, he was a supporter of <a href="Sheffield%20Wednesday%20F.C.">Sheffield Wednesday F.C.</a>, and would attend their matches most Saturdays. He died in Nottingham in 1958.
